revisions.rev:
{{Use mdy dates|date=October 2010}} {{Infobox summit | summit_name = G20 Summit on Financial Markets and the World Economy | other_titles = | image = 2010 G20 Seoul summit logo.JPG | caption = | date = November 11â12, 2010 | country = South Korea | venues = [[COEX Convention & Exhibition Center]], [[Seoul]], South Korea | participants = [[G-20 major economies|G-20]] (+ [[Ethiopia]], [[Malawi]], [[Singapore]], [[Spain]], [[Vietnam]]), [[ASEAN]], [[African Union|AU]], [[Financial Stability Board|FSB]], [[2010 G-20 Seoul summit#Attendance|3G]], [[International Labour Organization|ILO]], [[International Monetary Fund|IMF]], [[New Partnership for Africa's Development|NEPAD]], [[Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development|OECD]], UN, [[World Bank Group|WBG]], [[World Trade Organization|WTO]] | follows = [[2010 G-20 Toronto summit|Toronto summit, 2010]] | precedes = [[2011 G-20 Cannes summit|Cannes summit, 2011]] | website = [http://www.seoulsummit.kr seoulsummit.kr] }} The '''2010 G20 Seoul Summit''' was the [[List of G-20 summits|fifth meeting]] of the [[G-20 major economies|G-20]] [[Head of government|heads of government]], to discuss the [[global financial system]] and the [[world economy]],Cho Jin-seo. [http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/biz/2010/07/123_69053.html "Seoul unveils G20 summit's symbol,"] ''Korea Times'' (ROK). July 8, 2010; retrieved 10 Nov 2010. which took place in [[Seoul]], South Korea on November 11â12, 2010. Korea was the first non-[[G8]] nation to host a G-20 Leaders Summit.Oliver, Christian. "Seoul: S Korea looks forward to its own party," ''Financial Times'' (UK). June 25, 2010. The G20 is the premier forum for discussing, planning and monitoring international economic cooperation.Parliament (UK): Townsend, Ian. [http://www.parliament.uk/briefingpapers/commons/lib/research/briefings/snep-05028.pdf "G20 & the November 2010 Seoul summit" (SN/EP/5028)], 19 October 2010, retrieved 2011-04-07; excerpt, "Today, we designated the G-20 as the premier forum for our international economic cooperation" citing [http://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:gTcw3OEbzSkJ:www.g20.org/Documents/pittsburgh_summit_leaders_statement_250909.pdf+Pittsburgh+G20+Leaders%E2%80%99+summit+communiqu%C3%A9&hl=en&gl=us&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEESgX9FHigBaPzkGW9Wb3upzotx0Y_mQM_6OLscOkat_e3zksfLRbPZXdpSlHE2V5iTLvwCJf0EX7atRAqNaVYDCO9qiuAPcb6PkcxRuBikMzd6b8nKERQAwdr6vczsRKdau6FEMa&sig=AHIEtbTqzVyf8ZM5uYXbe-EdOm2B6-OuDg "Pittsburgh G20 Leadersâ summit communiquÃ©," Â¶50] September 29, 2009, retrieved 2011-04-07; excerpt, "Today, we designated the G-20 as the premier forum for our international economic cooperation. We have asked our representatives to report back at the next meeting with recommendations on how to maximize the effectiveness of our cooperation. We agreed to have a G-20 Summit in Canada in June 2010, and in Korea in November 2010. We expect to meet annually thereafter, and will meet in France in 2011. The theme of the summit was "Shared Growth Beyond Crisis."[http://english.yonhapnews.co.kr/n_g20/2010/07/20/6300000000AEN20100720005700315.HTML "G-20 preparation committee adopts catchphrase 'Shared growth beyond crisis',"] Yonhap News Agency. July 20, 2010; retrieved 05 Mar 2011. == Agenda == The summit leaders addressed several mid- and long-term policy issues,Il SaKong, Amar Bhattacharya, Mahani Zainal Abidin, Marcus Noland. [http://forum.eastwestcenter.org/eastwestdialogue/2010/04/29/new-issue-on-the-g20-2010-seoul-summit/ "Shaping the G20 Agenda in Asia: The 2010 Seoul Summit,"] ''East-West Dialogue'' (US) April 29, 2010; retrieved 10 Nov 2010. including * Ensuring global economic recoveryG20 Seoul summit, [http://seoulsummit.kr/eng/goPage.g20?menu_seq=G20MENU00059&return_url=T Agenda] * Framework for strong, sustainable, and balanced global growth * Strengthening the international financial regulatory system * Modernizing the international financial institutions * Global financial safety netsG20 Seoul summit, [http://seoulsummit.kr/eng/goPage.g20?return_url=TOP01_SUB03_02 New agenda and initiatives] * Development issues * The risk of a [[currency war]] Representatives met in advance of the leaders' summit. These [[Sherpa (emissary)|sherpas]] were tasked to draft a closing statement for the summit. The debate over currency exchange rates and imbalances was reported to have been "heated."Kaiser, Emily and David Chance. [http://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE6A90AC20101110 "G20 Deputies' Meeting 'heated" Spokesman Says,"] Reuters (UK). November 9, 2010; retrieved 9 Nov 2010. == Preparations == {{Main|2010 G-20 Seoul summit preparations}} The summit logo incorporates two images: (a) the sun rising over the sea; and (b) a traditional Korean lantern (''[[cheongsachorong]]''). Originally, three new [[artificial islands]] built on the [[Han River (Korea)|Han River]] between the [[Banpo Bridge|Banpo]] and [[Dongjak Bridge|Dongjak bridges]] were going to be used as the main summit venue.Kang Shin-who. [http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2010/01/113_58782.html "Seoul to Host G20 Summit on 'Floating Islands' on Han River,"] ''Korea Times'' (ROK). January 10, 2010; retrieved 10 Nov 2010. However, delayed construction of the islands led for the main summit venue to relocate to [[COEX Convention & Exhibition Center]]. The [[Republic of Korea Armed Forces]] and [[Seoul Metropolitan Police Agency]] provided security for the summit venues and the vicinity. ===Transportation=== Most world leaders and international media arrived via [[Incheon International Airport]] and traveled to the summit venue via motorcades along the highway from the airport. Transportation around the summit venue was upgraded with electric buses to help media and others around the city. ==Attendance== [[File:Obama and ErdoÄan speaking.jpg|thumb|right|American President Obama and Turkish Prime Minister ErdoÄan in conversation.]] The participants of the Seoul summit included the leaders and representatives of core members of the [[G-20 major economies]], which comprises 19 countries and the European Union which is represented by its two governing bodies, the [[European Council]] and the [[European Commission]],Rieffel, Lex. [http://www.brookings.edu/opinions/2009/0327_global_governance_rieffel.aspx "Regional Voices in Global Governance: Looking to 2010 (Part IV),"] Brookings (US). March 27, 2009; retrieved 10 Nov 2010; [http://g20.gc.ca/about-the-g20/g20-members/ "core" members (G20 official site)] Representatives from other nations and regional organizations were invited to take part in the summit. The South Korean government declined to invite the Netherlands, which had been invited to attend all four previous G20 summits. A Korean spokesman said that "a certain region had been over-represented" in the past; and for this Asian summit, [[Singapore]] was invited.Cho Jin-seo [http://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/biz/2010/09/301_73469.html Five non-G20 nations invited to Seoul Summit] ''[[Korea Times]]'' (ROK). September 24, 2010; retrieved 10 Nov 2010 This was the first summit at which there were four women among the leaders. In addition to President Kirchner of Argentina, Prime Minister Gillard of Australia, and Chancellor Merkel of Germany, the president-elect of Brazil, [[Dilma Rousseff]], accompanied her nation's delegation.Phillips, Tom. [http://www.guardian.co.uk/politics/2010/nov/12/g20-summit-women-dilma-rousseff "Will the G20 summit put women at the top of the agenda?"] ''Guardian'' (UK). November 10, 2010. The was the first G20 summit for Australia's Prime Minister Gillard, who was only elected shortly before the [[2010 G-20 Toronto summit|Toronto summit]].O'Malley, Sandra. {{cite news|url=http://news.smh.com.au/breaking-news-world/swan-to-take-international-stage-at-g20-20100626-zahn.html|title=Swan to take International Stage at G20|publisher=''Sydney Morning Herald'' (Australia)|date= June 26, 2010|accessdate=2010-09-28 | first=Sandra | last=O'Malley}} This was also the first opportunity for Prime Minister [[Lee Hsien Loong]] of Singapore to listen and to make his voice heard at the G20 leaders' meetings. {| class="wikitable" |- ! colspan="4" style="background: LightSteelBlue;"|'''[[G-20 major economies|G-20 members]]'''

November 11, 2010; retrieved 11 Nov 2010. | Director-General |} ==Security== Security for the G-20 summit presented a unique array of problems. In addition to the security of the main venue, [[COEX Convention & Exhibition Center|COEX]], South Korea was more broadly responsible for providing a safe venue for the delegations who come to the summit. The [[National Police Agency (South Korea)|National Police Agency]] led the security detail for the summit, both at the convention venue and the airport as well. Other police and security agencies involved were: * [[Presidential Security Service]] * [[National Intelligence Service (South Korea)|National Intelligence Service]] * [[Ministry of National Defense (Republic of Korea)|Ministry of National Defense]] * [[Ministry of Public Administration and Security (South Korea)|National Emergency Management Agency]] [[File:G20 protests Seoul - VOA - police.jpg|thumb|right|A squad of riot police in front of the Korea Press Center in downtown Seoul — 7 November 2010]] [[File:G20 protests Seoul - VOA - labor protesters.jpg|thumb|right|Demonstrators converged on downtown Seoul in protest against the G20 leaders' summit. The labor rally took place in Seoul City Plaza near city hall — 7 November 2010]] In preparation, anti-terrorism drills were held by members of the South Korean police, military, special forces and private sector as part of the 2010 [[Ulchi-Freedom Guardian]] exercises against simulated hostage situations and chemical, biological and radiological attacks as a preparation for the summit.[http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-11012416 "South Korea stages anti-terror drill,"] ''BBC News'' (UK). August 18, 2010; retrieved 10 Nov 2010 Plans for accommodating peaceful protesters were paired with plans for mitigating disruptive demonstrations. The G-20 raised security concerns unrelated to demonstrators protesting the presence of the leaders of 20 economies in Seoul. For example, some analysts projected that anything perceived as a success for South Korea would be simultaneously construed in [[Pyongyang]] as a threat to North Korea.Kirk, Donald. [http://www.atimes.com/atimes/Korea/LG07Dg01.html "Seoul wary of success backlash,"] ''Asia Times'' (Hong Kong). July 7, 2010; retrieved 10 Nov 2010 ==Criticism, Protests, and Controversies== The G-20 has long been a target of protests and counter-summits by the [[global justice movement]], [[environmentalists]], [[anti-capitalists]], and other progressive transnational activist networks. For example, G-20 meetings in [[2010 G-20 Toronto summit protests|Toronto]], [[2009 G-20 London summit protests|London]], and [[2009_G-20_Pittsburgh_summit#Protests|Pittsburgh]] all experienced mass protests and countersummit activities, and the Seoul summit was no exception. Activists criticized the G20 for undermining workers' rights, pressuring governments to cut social programs, and contributing to environmentally destructive policies.[http://english.chosun.com/site/data/html_dir/2010/11/08/2010110800551.html Tens of Thousands Protest G20 Summit in Seoul] The Sunday before the summit, an estimated 20-40,000 protesters marched peacefully in opposition to the G20 summit and to the [[US-Korea Free Trade Agreement]].{{cite news| url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2010/11/07/us-korea-protest-idUSTRE6A61CP20101107 | work=Reuters | title=Thousands protest in Seoul before G20 summit | date=November 7, 2010}} The [[Korean Confederation of Trade Unions]] (KCTU), together with other labor unions, NGOs, and activists, organized a 'People's Week of Collective Action,' as well as a 'People's Summit' where thousands gathered to discuss alternative proposals on jobs, labour rights, financial regulation, climate change, Free Trade Agreements, [[food sovereignty]], poverty, migration, [[Intellectual Property Rights]], and more.[http://kctu.org/9845 KCTU Calls for international participation in Peopleâs Week of Collective Action protesting G20 Seoul Summit] September, 2010 On the opening day of the summit, a protest of thousands was marred by police violence.[http://www.demotix.com/news/504574/g20-protests-seoul] The protests and countersummit were documented extensively by independent media such as [http://korea.indymedia.org Korea Indymedia], [http://www.demotix.com/news/504574/g20-protests-seoul demotix], and [http://blog.jinbo.net/noG20/ Jinbonet]. In addition, * There was an incident where a university instructor vandalized a G-20 promotional poster by drawing a rat. The letter G in English sounds much like the Korean word "ì¥," which means "mouse" or "rat."[http://news.khan.co.kr/kh_news/khan_art_view.html?artid=201011030454205&code=940301 G20 íë³´ ==Outcome== Despite public endorsements by attending leaders, most commentators looking back on the summit have argued that only limited progress was made, especially on the headline issue of currency war and addressing trade imbalances.{{cite news | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-11739748 | title = G20 to tackle US-China currency concerns | publisher = BBC | author = Andrew Walker and other BBC staff | date = 2010-11-12 | accessdate = 2010-11-17}} {{cite web | url = http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/e65d6a44-ee2e-11df-8b90-00144feab49a,dwp_uuid=60a3db68-b177-11dd-b97a-0000779fd18c.html#axzz15XF7OoVU | title = G20 shuns US on trade and currencies | publisher = [[The Financial Times]] | author = Chris Giles, Alan Beattie and Christian Oliver in Seoul | date = 2010-11-12 | accessdate = 2010-11-12}} {{cite web | url = http://english.aljazeera.net/focus/2010/11/20101111135923477349.html | title = Currency 'wars' dominate G20 summit | publisher = [[Aljazeera]] | author = Gabriel Elizondo | date = 2010-11-11 | accessdate = 2010-11-12}} {{cite web | url = http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/e65d6a44-ee2e-11df-8b90-00144feab49a.html#axzz154Rga7o2 | title = G20 fails to reach deal on imbalances | publisher = [[The Financial Times]] | author = Chris Giles, Alan Beattie and Christian Oliver in Seoul | date = 2010-11-12 | accessdate = 2010-11-12}} {{cite news | title = G20 pledge to avoid currency war gets lukewarm reception | accessdate = 2010-11-13 | url = http://www.guardian.co.uk/business/2010/nov/12/g20-leaders-pledge-to-avoid-currency-war | publisher = The Guardian | author = Phillip Inman and Patrick Wintour in Seoul | date = 2010-11-12 | location = London}}{{cite news | url = http://online.wsj.com/article/SB20001424052748704865704575610761647291510.html | title = U.S. Gets Rebuffed At Divided Summit | accessdate = 2010-11-13 | publisher = The Wall Street Journal | author = Evan ramstad | date = 2010-11-19}}{{cite web | url = http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-11-17/three-reasons-global-talks-hit-dead-end-mohamed-a-el-erian.html | title = Three Reasons Global Talks Hit Dead End: Mohamed A. El-Erian | publisher = [[Bloomberg L.P.]] | date = 2010-11-17 | author = [[Mohamed A. El-Erian]] | accessdate = 2010-11-19}} Leaders were generally unable to agree on key issues, with commentators such as economist [[Eswar Prasad]] noting the absence of the sense of unity that had been present at summits during the worse of the [[financial crisis of 2007â2010|global financial crisis of 2007 -2009]]. IMF managing director [[Dominique Strauss-Kahn]] said this particular summit was "more of a G20 debate than a G20 conclusion". Relating to the need to [[Balance of payments#Imbalances|rebalance]] the world economy, agreement had been reached to work on indicative guidelines which will set suggested maximum limits for [[current account]] surpluses and deficits, though these are not due to be fleshed out until 2011. G20 leaders also agreed to endorse the [[Seoul Development Consensus]] , a set of guidelines and principles for working together with less development nations to improve economic growth and reduce poverty. In contrast to the older [[Washington Consensus]] which it supersedes, the Seoul Consensus is less free market orientated, allowing a bigger role for state intervention.{{cite news | url = http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748704865704575610612606532370.html | title = G-20's Host Pushes Seoul Consensus | accessdate = 2010-11-13 | publisher = The Wall Street Journal | author = Evan ramstad | date = 2010-11-17}}{{cite web | url = http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/1423f75e-ee61-11df-8b90-00144feab49a,dwp_uuid=60a3db68-b177-11dd-b97a-0000779fd18c.html#axzz15XG6rHkB | title = Forget summit failures, look at G20 record | publisher = [[The Financial Times]] | author = By Christian Oliver, Chris Giles and Alan Beattie in Seoul | date = 2010-11-12 | accessdate = 2010-11-17}} == See
